title: Is snowballing getting out of control?
body:
I just returned to league after a six month break. Since returning, I have noticed that snowballing seems to be at a level I haven't seen in years.

In many games, if a lane gets even a single kill early it's pretty much over. That lane then snowballs and there isn't much hope for the player who died to make a comeback.

What are your thoughts on this?

replies.body: Nah, certainly some games feel like stomps but no where near as bad as last preseason with the 25 min games.  That was snowballing out of control.  Stalling is actually an option now.

I do find games go longer right now. But individual lane snowball is real. It just seems the ability to carry off of your won lane isn't enough and is becoming even more team oriented which is good and bad.
There was a time when snowball was out of control

Okay that's fine, downvote me for making an obvious point that disagrees with you. 

A "snowballing" champion is designed to have significant power spikes by out-leveling their opponent. These are more often "mid game" champions because as long as they are able to gain an early level advantage they can beat their enemies before they reach the level cap and their opponent is able to catch up. 

The alternatives are "early game" champions and "late game" champions. Early game champions are more often able to bully mid game champions which keeps them from getting out of control. They have higher base stats and do not scale as well. Late game champions are more often item dependent. If they can survive long enough they will most likely be the strongest. 

And of course with 134 available champions, it is ridiculous to attempt to divide all of them up into 3 categories. Many champions have differing degrees of strength during each phase of the match. Some scale consistently throughout the whole match, others are early and mid, some are mid and late, others are early and late. Furthermore the outcome of any given match is even more difficult to be determined when a team is comprised of a combination of 5 of the aforementioned snowflakes (no pun intended, ... well, maybe a little intended), and then there is the actual knowledge and skill of the person sitting on the other side of the keyboard. 

So in summary, any champion who is infact "snowballing" will be "out of control" until they are no longer "snowballing"

I know that snowball champs have always existed, but what I'm talking about is not about a single champ or group of champs.

 It's about every single game feeling very very feast or famine. Regardless of champion roster, games seem to be detrmined in the first 5-10mins.

In the past, it has felt like if I had a poor start I could play safe, farm up, and my team would still have a shot mid to late as long as we didn't yield too many objectives. 

Currently it feels like one mistake and the game is no longer winnable.

This isn't just about losing. I have had plenty of matches were I got a kill early and that lane was pretty much over. 

I see this mostly in the bot lane now, but it applies to all lanes. 

I'm not complaining about specific champions designed to snowball.
Well, that is kinda how snowballing is supposed to work ...

Thanks for your useless post though.

Riot has always attempted to reduce snowballing because it isn't healthy for the game. However, it seems that games are very one sided. Within the first five minutes, the game is usually won or lost.

I have yet to have a match that isn't a steamroll victory or a FF at 20.
